thread.title: Heathrow and Gatwick report record travel numbers for June amid runway fight
thread.title_full: Heathrow and Gatwick report record travel numbers for June amid runway fight | Daily Mail Online

author: Chris Kitching for MailOnline
title: Heathrow and Gatwick report record travel numbers for June amid runway fight
text:
9 shares 6
View
comments
Heathrow and Gatwick say they had their busiest June on record last month, as the airports continue to spar for the right to build the UK’s newest runway.
According to figures released this week the busy summer travel period got off to a big start at both airports in June, with Heathrow reporting a record 6.68million passengers and the smaller Gatwick reporting 3.8million.
Both airports said the figures boost their case for expansion, with Prime Minister David Cameron previously saying the Tories would make a decision on a new runway by the end of the year.
With a year-on-year increase of five per cent, Gatwick said it achieved its 28th consecutive month of growth
Heathrow said its passenger count was an increase of 1.1 per cent on June 2014, and it also set a new record for aircraft movements with 40,626 flights last month.
With a year-on-year increase of five per cent, Gatwick said it achieved its 28th consecutive month of passenger traffic growth thanks to having more arrivals and departures per hour, with a total of 24,541 aircraft movements.
Heathrow attributed its increase to more flights using ‘larger, quieter aircraft’ – an apparent reference to critics or residents who have expressed concerns about noise if a new runway is built at one of the world’s busiest airports.

Heathrow said passenger traffic spiked for travel between London and Mexico (23.6 per cent), China (15.2 per cent) and Turkey (3.4 per cent).
At Gatwick, officials said the airport has had 12 months of consecutive growth for long-haul routes, with the biggest increases in passenger traffic involving destinations in the US (20.6 per cent), United Arab Emirates (11.7 per cent) and the Caribbean and Latin America (8.1 per cent).
Both airports released duelling statements on why they deserve to take on a new runway.
Heathrow said passenger traffic spiked for travel between London and Mexico, China and Turkey
Heathrow CEO John Holland-Kaye said: ‘On the first of July, the Airports Commission ended the debate on where a new runway should be built by unanimously recommending Heathrow’s new expansion plan.
‘It’s now a binary choice for the British Government. We either expand Heathrow – creating jobs, growth, a rebalanced economy and lucrative export routes – or we do nothing and retreat as a nation.
‘The answer is obvious, so let’s get on with it.’
Gatwick has dismissed the Airports Commission's report as flawed and unfair as it was based on old figures.
Gatwick CEO Stewart Wingate said: ‘Gatwick remains the best option for expansion as it can cater for all airline types flying to all types of destination – this is clearly illustrated by the growth in the numbers of passengers choosing long haul services at Gatwick.
‘We will continue to engage actively with government at all levels to show why Gatwick expansion is the only means by which we can sustain the low cost revolution that has driven aviation growth over the last two decades, and the only choice which can actually deliver the aviation capacity that the UK desperately needs.'
